title: Brandon looking for right fit in Armour
text:
Brandon looking for right fit in Armour By: Perry Bergson Enlarge Image 
Garrett Armour takes Brandon Wheat King Reid Duke into the boards in a Nov. 7, 2014 game at Westman Place. The Wheat Kings acquired Armour from the Saskatoon Blades on Thursday. (FILE PHOTO) 
If familiarity with the Brandon Wheat Kings is any indicator of success, the team’s newest left-winger could be a hit. 
Garrett Armour, an 18-year-old Winnipeg product who was acquired from the Saskatoon Blades on Thursday, said he is happy with the opportunity he’s been given in part because he has friends on the team. 
"Nolan Patrick, I’ve grown up with him since we were seven and he lives probably within five or 10 minutes of me (in Winnipeg)," Armour said. "I see that guy lots during the summer. Mark Taraschuk, I know him really well and played against him a lot." 
He also knows Tanner Kaspick and Kale Clague from playing against them. 
The Wheat Kings sent a conditional 2017 Western Hockey League draft pick to Saskatoon for the chance to give Armour an audition. 
He played 45 games with the Blades last season, posting one goal, five assists and 60 penalty minutes. The six-foot-two, 212-pound Armour was originally selected by the Edmonton Oil Kings in the seventh round of the 2012 WHL bantam draft. 
Wheat Kings head coach and general manager Kelly McCrimmon said the Blades have a lot of young players who need ice time, a situation that impacted Armour. 
He said the winger could potentially be a good addition. 
Armour adds "depth up front, experience — he’s been in the league for a year — size and strength, good skater," McCrimmon said. "It’s more depth at the forward position. Guys like Garrett, sometimes it’s about fit. We’ll see if there is a fit for him here. I think he has something to offer." 
Armour said he had an inkling a deal was in the offing but added it was still a shock when he officially found out. The destination made it all worthwhile. 
"This was definitely the number one place I would have liked to go," Armour said. 
He said he is a power forward who likes to keep his game simple, getting pucks deep, banging bodies and fighting if required. 
"Obviously it’s a team that knows how to win," Armour said. "Hopefully I can contribute to that."
